lessons.title: Welcome to End-of-Life Doula Work: An Overview
outline: The growing need for end-of-life doulas: Addressing gaps in current end-of-life care, statistics on hospice utilization, and patient/family needs.
Defining the End-of-Life Doula Role: Differentiating from hospice, palliative care, and other healthcare professionals; scope of practice; ethical considerations.
The P.E.A.C.E. Framework™ Introduction: Overview of the framework and its application throughout the course. Initial focus on Presence & Perspective (P).
Benefits of End-of-Life Doula Support: Improved quality of life for clients, reduced caregiver burden, enhanced communication, and promoting a peaceful death.
Exploring Personal Motivations: Self-reflection on personal values, beliefs about death, and reasons for pursuing end-of-life doula work. Recognizing personal boundaries and self-care needs.

lessons.title: Crafting Your Doula Vision and Mission
outline: Defining Your Ideal Client: Identifying specific populations you are drawn to serve (e.g., specific age groups, illnesses, cultural backgrounds).
Identifying Your Unique Strengths and Skills: Reflecting on personal qualities, professional background, and life experiences that make you a valuable doula.
Developing a Personal Mission Statement: Articulating your core purpose and values as an end-of-life doula. Examples and templates provided.
Setting Realistic Goals: Establishing short-term and long-term goals for your doula practice, considering time commitment, financial needs, and desired impact.
Addressing Potential Challenges: Identifying common obstacles faced by new doulas (e.g., marketing, client acquisition, emotional burnout) and developing coping strategies.

lessons.title: Ethical Considerations and Scope of Practice
outline: Defining Boundaries: Understanding the limits of the end-of-life doula role and when to refer to other professionals (e.g., medical doctors, therapists, lawyers).
Confidentiality and Privacy: Adhering to ethical guidelines regarding client information and respecting their right to privacy. HIPAA considerations (if applicable).
Informed Consent: Ensuring clients understand the services you provide and have the autonomy to make their own decisions. The importance of clear communication.
Avoiding Dual Relationships: Recognizing and avoiding potential conflicts of interest that could compromise your objectivity and impartiality.
Ethical Dilemmas: Exploring common ethical challenges faced by end-of-life doulas and developing a framework for ethical decision-making. Case studies and group discussion.

lessons.title: Building a Sustainable Doula Practice
outline: Networking and Collaboration: Connecting with other healthcare professionals, community organizations, and support groups to build referral networks.
Marketing Your Services: Developing a marketing plan to reach your target audience, including online presence, social media, and community outreach.
Setting Fees and Payment Options: Determining your pricing structure and offering flexible payment options to make your services accessible.
Legal and Business Considerations: Understanding the legal requirements for operating a doula practice in your area, including business licenses and insurance.
Self-Care and Burnout Prevention: Implementing strategies for managing stress, maintaining boundaries, and preventing emotional burnout. The importance of ongoing support and supervision.
Continuing Education and Professional Development: Staying current with best practices and expanding your knowledge through workshops, conferences, and mentorship opportunities.

lessons.title: The Foundation of Presence: Defining the End-of-Life Doula Role
outline: Defining the role of an End-of-Life Doula: scope of practice, boundaries, and ethical considerations.
Differentiating the doula role from other healthcare professionals (hospice, palliative care, social workers).
Understanding the importance of self-awareness and personal values in end-of-life care.
Exploring the PEACE Framework™ and its application to end-of-life support; focusing on the 'P' - Presence & Perspective.
Establishing professional boundaries and self-care strategies to prevent burnout and maintain objectivity.

lessons.title: Cultivating Mindful Presence: Active Listening and Observation Skills
outline: Defining and practicing mindful presence: being fully present in the moment without judgment.
Developing active listening skills: techniques for truly hearing and understanding the client's needs and concerns.
Non-verbal communication: interpreting body language, facial expressions, and tone of voice to gain deeper insights.
Using silence effectively: creating space for reflection and emotional processing.
Recognizing and managing personal biases and emotional reactions during client interactions.

lessons.title: Understanding Perspectives on Mortality: Cultural, Spiritual, and Personal Beliefs
outline: Exploring diverse cultural perspectives on death, dying, and the afterlife.
Understanding the role of spirituality and religion in shaping individual beliefs about mortality.
Recognizing and respecting the client's unique personal values and beliefs, regardless of personal agreement.
Identifying common fears and anxieties associated with death and dying (e.g., pain, loss of control, being a burden).
Creating a safe and non-judgmental space for clients to express their beliefs and fears.

lessons.title: Values Clarification: Helping Clients Identify What Matters Most
outline: Understanding the importance of values clarification in end-of-life care.
Introducing various values clarification exercises and tools to help clients identify their core values.
Guiding clients in reflecting on how their values align with their end-of-life wishes and goals.
Documenting identified values and preferences for future reference and decision-making.
Addressing potential conflicts between values and practical considerations (e.g., financial constraints, family dynamics).

lessons.title: Exploring Wishes and Preferences: End-of-Life Planning Conversations
outline: Initiating conversations about end-of-life wishes and preferences in a sensitive and supportive manner.
Using open-ended questions to encourage clients to share their thoughts and feelings about their ideal end-of-life experience.
Discussing various aspects of end-of-life care, including medical interventions, comfort measures, and spiritual practices.
Addressing common misconceptions and providing accurate information about end-of-life options.
Documenting the client's wishes and preferences in a clear and concise manner.

lessons.title: The Power of Story: Understanding the Client's Narrative
outline: Recognizing the importance of the client's life story in understanding their present needs and concerns.
Using narrative therapy techniques to help clients reflect on their life experiences, accomplishments, and regrets.
Identifying recurring themes and patterns in the client's narrative to gain deeper insights into their values and beliefs.
Facilitating the creation of legacy projects (e.g., writing letters, creating memory boxes, recording oral histories) to preserve the client's story.
Honoring the client's story and validating their experiences.

lessons.title: Navigating Family Dynamics: Understanding Interpersonal Relationships
outline: Understanding the impact of family dynamics on the end-of-life experience.
Identifying potential sources of conflict and tension within the family system.
Developing strategies for facilitating communication and resolving conflicts among family members.
Recognizing the roles and responsibilities of different family members in providing care and support.
Supporting the client in maintaining healthy relationships with their loved ones.

lessons.title: Self-Reflection and Continued Learning: Embracing the Journey
outline: The importance of ongoing self-reflection and professional development for end-of-life doulas.
Techniques for processing challenging emotions and experiences encountered in end-of-life care.
Seeking supervision and support from experienced doulas or mentors.
Staying up-to-date on current research and best practices in end-of-life care.
Embracing the ongoing learning process and recognizing the transformative power of the end-of-life experience.
Review of the PEACE Framework™ and how 'Presence & Perspective' lays the groundwork for subsequent stages.

lessons.title: Navigating Difficult Conversations: Fears and Beliefs About Death
outline: Understanding common fears surrounding death and dying (pain, loss of control, separation, the unknown).
Techniques for initiating and guiding sensitive conversations about mortality.
Identifying and addressing personal biases and assumptions about death to provide unbiased support.
Exploring the client's existing belief systems (religious, spiritual, philosophical) and how they influence their perception of death.
Practical exercises: Role-playing scenarios for handling difficult questions and emotional responses.

lessons.title: End-of-Life Options: A Comprehensive Overview
outline: Detailed explanation of hospice care: eligibility, services provided, and the role of the hospice team.
Understanding palliative care: how it differs from hospice, when it's appropriate, and its benefits.
Overview of medical aid in dying: legal considerations, eligibility criteria, and ethical implications (where applicable).
Exploring the option of voluntary stopping of eating and drinking (VSED): considerations and support.
Discussing the role of comfort care and symptom management in various end-of-life scenarios.

lessons.title: Practical Considerations: Legal and Financial Planning
outline: Understanding the importance of advance care planning: living wills, durable power of attorney for healthcare.
Explanation of wills and trusts: how they ensure the client's wishes are honored regarding property and assets.
Overview of common financial concerns at the end of life: insurance, debts, and estate taxes.
Resources for legal and financial assistance: organizations and professionals who can provide guidance.

lessons.title: Understanding Grief: Processes, Theories, and Support
outline: Exploring different models of grief (e.g., Kübler-Ross model, dual process model) and their limitations.
Recognizing common symptoms of grief: emotional, physical, cognitive, and behavioral.
Differentiating between normal grief and complicated grief (persistent complex bereavement disorder).
Strategies for supporting grieving individuals: active listening, empathy, and validation.
Identifying local grief resources: support groups, therapists, and bereavement centers.

lessons.title: Rituals and Ceremony: Honoring Life and Saying Goodbye

Examples of meaningful rituals: memorial services, celebrations of life, creating memory boxes, writing letters.
Guiding clients in designing personalized rituals that reflect their values and preferences.
Incorporating elements of spirituality and symbolism into rituals to provide comfort and meaning.
Addressing logistical considerations for planning and executing rituals.

lessons.title: Communication Strategies: Active Listening and Empathetic Response

Non-verbal communication: the importance of body language, tone of voice, and eye contact.

lessons.title: Legacy Projects: Creating Meaning and Remembrance

Examples of legacy projects: writing memoirs, creating photo albums, recording video messages, composing music.

Providing practical assistance with legacy project creation: resources, tools, and creative ideas.
Addressing potential emotional challenges associated with legacy work: facing mortality, reflecting on life choices.

lessons.title: Self-Care for the Doula: Managing Emotional Boundaries and Preventing Burnout
outline: Recognizing the emotional demands of end-of-life doula work and the risk of burnout.
Developing strategies for setting and maintaining healthy emotional boundaries with clients and families.
Implementing self-care practices to manage stress, promote well-being, and prevent compassion fatigue.
The importance of supervision and peer support for processing difficult experiences and maintaining professional effectiveness.
Accessing resources for doula self-care: support groups, therapists, and continuing education opportunities.

lessons.title: Understanding Advance Care Planning: A Doula's Role

Navigating cultural and religious considerations in ACP.
Documenting ACP wishes and ensuring accessibility to relevant parties (family, healthcare providers).

lessons.title: Facilitating Values-Based Conversations

Tools and frameworks for values clarification exercises (e.g., the 'Values Auction,' 'The Good Death Inventory').
Identifying potential conflicts between client values and medical recommendations; strategies for respectful dialogue.
Addressing common fears and anxieties related to death and dying during values-based conversations.
Documenting and summarizing client values to inform ACP discussions and advocacy efforts.

lessons.title: Navigating Legal and Ethical Considerations in End-of-Life Care
outline: Overview of relevant laws and regulations governing end-of-life care in different jurisdictions (e.g., state-specific advance directive laws, physician-assisted dying legislation).

lessons.title: Connecting Clients with Resources: Building a Professional Network

Building relationships with healthcare providers, social workers, clergy, and other professionals in the end-of-life field.
Understanding the scope of practice for different healthcare professionals and how to collaborate effectively.
Creating a referral network to ensure clients have access to comprehensive support services.
Advocating for improved access to end-of-life care resources in the community.

lessons.title: Advocating for Client Autonomy and Preferences

Strategies for communicating client preferences to healthcare providers and family members effectively.

Documenting advocacy efforts and outcomes to ensure accountability and transparency.

lessons.title: Practical Considerations: Completing and Implementing Advance Directives
outline: Step-by-step guidance on completing advance directive forms: Living Wills, DPOAH, and POLST.
Ensuring that advance directives are properly witnessed and notarized according to state law.
Strategies for storing and accessing advance directives in electronic health records and other secure locations.
Facilitating communication between clients, healthcare providers, and family members regarding advance directive wishes.
Addressing common challenges in implementing advance directives (e.g., lack of awareness, resistance from family members).

lessons.title: Addressing Specific Scenarios: Dementia, MAID, and Unexpected Death

Supporting families in the event of unexpected death: providing immediate emotional support and guidance on practical arrangements.
Understanding the role of grief support and bereavement resources in helping families cope with loss.

lessons.title: Documentation, Boundaries, and Self-Care in Advocacy

Recognizing the signs of burnout and compassion fatigue in advocacy work.
Implementing self-care strategies to manage stress and maintain emotional resilience.

lessons.title: The Foundation of Comfort: Understanding Client Needs

Creating a safe and supportive space for clients to express their emotions and concerns.
Facilitating opportunities for reminiscence, life review, and meaning-making.
Recognizing signs of complicated grief and providing appropriate support or referral.

lessons.title: Spiritual Comfort: Exploring Meaning, Purpose, and Connection

lessons.title: The Art of Presence: Being a Calm and Compassionate Companion

Using non-verbal communication to convey empathy, compassion, and support.
Creating a calming and peaceful atmosphere: minimizing distractions and promoting relaxation.
Holding space for silence and allowing clients to lead the conversation.
Practicing self-care to avoid burnout and maintain emotional well-being.

lessons.title: Facilitating Connection: Strengthening Bonds with Loved Ones
outline: Identifying and addressing barriers to connection: communication difficulties, unresolved conflicts, and emotional distress.
Facilitating meaningful conversations between clients and loved ones.
Supporting family members in providing comfort and care.
Encouraging rituals and traditions that promote connection: sharing stories, looking at photos, and listening to music.
Creating opportunities for reconciliation and forgiveness.

outline: Assisting with activities of daily living: bathing, dressing, eating, and toileting.
Managing finances and legal matters: paying bills, updating wills, and accessing benefits.
Coordinating care and support services: home health, hospice, and respite care.
Providing information and resources on end-of-life planning and decision-making.

lessons.title: Ethical Considerations: Boundaries, Confidentiality, and Respect

lessons.title: Embracing the Dying Process: Understanding Acceptance

lessons.title: Navigating Evolving End-of-Life Plans
outline: Understanding the dynamic nature of end-of-life plans and the importance of flexibility.
Strategies for reassessing and adjusting care plans based on the client's changing needs and wishes.

lessons.title: Supporting Emotional Closure: Forgiveness and Reconciliation

lessons.title: Spiritual Closure and Legacy Work

Facilitating spiritual practices that promote peace and connection.
Exploring the concept of legacy and its importance in finding meaning at the end of life.
Guiding clients in creating legacy projects, such as writing letters, recording stories, or creating artwork.
Respecting diverse spiritual beliefs and practices.

lessons.title: Facilitating Meaningful Connections and Goodbyes
outline: Strategies for fostering meaningful connections between the client and their loved ones.
Creating opportunities for quality time and shared experiences.
Supporting the client in expressing their wishes for their final days and moments.
Facilitating meaningful goodbyes that honor the client's life and relationships.
Addressing anticipatory grief in family members.

lessons.title: Managing Physical Comfort in the Final Stages
outline: Recognizing signs and symptoms of physical distress in the dying client.

Providing comfort measures such as positioning, massage, and aromatherapy.
Understanding the role of palliative care and hospice in managing physical discomfort.

lessons.title: The Doula's Role After Death: Bereavement Support

lessons.title: Self-Care and Reflection for the End-of-Life Doula

Seeking supervision and support from colleagues and mentors.
Reflecting on personal experiences and lessons learned from working with dying clients and their families.

lessons.title: Spiritual Care: Honoring Beliefs and Values

lessons.title: Working with Diverse Populations: Cultural Competence and Sensitivity

lessons.title: Cultural Competency: Honoring Diverse Beliefs and Practices

Documenting wishes beyond medical directives: funeral arrangements, digital legacy, and personal mementos.
Utilizing the PEACE framework to ensure the client's values and priorities are reflected in their advanced care plan.

lessons.title: Spiritual Care: Addressing Existential Distress
outline: Recognizing signs of existential distress: questioning meaning and purpose, fear of the unknown, and spiritual isolation.
Utilizing spiritual assessment tools to understand the client's beliefs and values.
Offering spiritual support without imposing personal beliefs: active listening, guided meditation, and connecting with spiritual resources.
Addressing common spiritual concerns: forgiveness, reconciliation, and finding peace with mortality.
Differentiating between spiritual care and religious practice and respecting diverse belief systems.

lessons.title: Ethical Considerations in End-of-Life Doula Work
outline: Reviewing the doula's scope of practice and avoiding medical or legal advice.
Maintaining client confidentiality and privacy in accordance with HIPAA regulations.
Addressing potential conflicts of interest and dual relationships.
Navigating ethical dilemmas: requests for assisted dying, disagreements with family members, and reporting concerns of abuse or neglect.
Understanding the importance of professional boundaries and self-care to prevent burnout.

lessons.title: Cultural Competency: Honoring Diverse End-of-Life Traditions
outline: Exploring the influence of culture on beliefs about death, dying, and bereavement.
Understanding common cultural practices related to mourning, funeral rituals, and grief expression.
Developing strategies for providing culturally sensitive care: communication styles, dietary restrictions, and religious observances.
Addressing potential cultural conflicts: differing beliefs about pain management, end-of-life decision-making, and the role of family.
Resources for researching specific cultural traditions and connecting with cultural brokers.

lessons.title: Grief and Bereavement: Supporting Loved Ones
outline: Understanding the different types of grief: anticipatory grief, normal grief, complicated grief, and disenfranchised grief.
Providing emotional support to grieving family members: active listening, validation, and normalizing grief reactions.
Offering practical assistance with funeral arrangements, estate matters, and other logistical tasks.
Connecting bereaved individuals with grief support resources: support groups, individual counseling, and online communities.
Recognizing signs of prolonged grief disorder and making appropriate referrals.

lessons.title: Self-Care and Preventing Burnout for End-of-Life Doulas
outline: Recognizing the signs and symptoms of burnout: emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and reduced personal accomplishment.
Developing a self-care plan that includes physical, emotional, spiritual, and social well-being.
Implementing strategies for managing stress: mindfulness, meditation, exercise, and hobbies.
Setting healthy boundaries with clients and family members to protect personal time and energy.
Seeking supervision and peer support to process difficult experiences and prevent compassion fatigue.

lessons.title: Building Your End-of-Life Doula Practice
outline: Defining your target market and niche within the end-of-life doula field.
Developing a marketing strategy: website, social media, networking, and community outreach.
Creating a professional service agreement that outlines scope of practice, fees, and confidentiality.
Understanding legal and insurance considerations for doula businesses.
Building relationships with referral sources: hospices, hospitals, senior living communities, and funeral homes.
Strategies for long-term sustainability and growth of your doula practice.

lessons.title: Navigating Complex Family Dynamics: The Miller Case
outline: Presenting the Miller Case: An 87-year-old client with advanced dementia and conflicting desires among adult children regarding end-of-life care.
Applying the 'P' (Presence & Perspective) of the PEACE Framework: Assessing each family member's perspective and identifying underlying emotional needs and past conflicts.
Ethical considerations: Balancing autonomy, beneficence, non-maleficence, and justice in a complex family situation; understanding legal frameworks related to guardianship and healthcare proxies.

Facilitating Family Meetings: Strategies for mediating disagreements, promoting constructive communication, and reaching consensus on care decisions, including the use of professional mediators if necessary.
Documentation: Meticulously documenting all interactions, decisions, and the rationale behind them, including any dissenting opinions, to mitigate potential legal challenges.

lessons.title: Spiritual Distress and Existential Crisis: The Rodriguez Case
outline: Presenting the Rodriguez Case: A 52-year-old client facing a terminal cancer diagnosis, experiencing profound spiritual distress and questioning the meaning of life.
Applying the 'E' (Exploration & Education) of the PEACE Framework: Identifying the client's spiritual and existential concerns through active listening and empathetic inquiry.
Partnering with Spiritual Care Providers: Collaborating with chaplains, religious leaders, or spiritual counselors to provide specialized support and guidance.
Meaning-Making Interventions: Exploring techniques to help the client find meaning and purpose in the face of death, such as legacy projects, life review, and forgiveness exercises.
Addressing Spiritual Pain: Differentiating between spiritual distress and mental health conditions, and knowing when to refer to mental health professionals for specialized care.

lessons.title: Advanced Dementia and Non-Verbal Communication: The Chen Case
outline: Presenting the Chen Case: A 90-year-old client with advanced dementia who is largely non-verbal, requiring skilled interpretation of non-verbal cues.
Applying the 'A' (Action & Advocacy) of the PEACE Framework: Advocating for the client's comfort and dignity, ensuring their needs are met despite their inability to communicate verbally.
Non-Verbal Communication Techniques: Utilizing observation, touch, and environmental cues to understand the client's needs and preferences, including recognizing signs of pain or discomfort.
Working with Care Teams: Collaborating with nurses, physicians, and other healthcare professionals to develop a comprehensive care plan that addresses the client's specific needs.

Advance Care Planning in Dementia: Addressing the challenges of advance care planning in cases of progressive dementia, including the use of surrogate decision-makers and the importance of respecting previously expressed wishes.

lessons.title: Sudden and Traumatic Loss: The Davis Case
outline: Presenting the Davis Case: A 40-year-old client whose spouse died suddenly in an accident, experiencing acute grief and trauma.
Applying the 'C' (Comfort & Connection) of the PEACE Framework: Providing immediate emotional support and practical assistance to the client and their family.
Understanding Traumatic Grief: Recognizing the unique challenges of traumatic grief, including symptoms of PTSD, complicated grief, and survivor's guilt.
Grief Support Resources: Connecting the client with appropriate grief support resources, such as individual counseling, support groups, and community organizations.
Self-Care for the Doula: Recognizing the emotional toll of working with clients experiencing traumatic loss and implementing strategies for self-care and burnout prevention.

lessons.title: Pediatric End-of-Life Care: The Garcia Case
outline: Presenting the Garcia Case: A 7-year-old child with a terminal illness, requiring sensitive and compassionate care for both the child and their family.
Applying the 'E' (Embrace & Evolve) of the PEACE Framework: Supporting the family as they navigate the emotional, spiritual, and practical challenges of pediatric end-of-life care.
Communicating with Children: Adapting communication strategies to the child's developmental level, using age-appropriate language and addressing their fears and concerns.
Supporting Siblings: Recognizing the unique needs of siblings and providing them with emotional support and opportunities to express their grief.
Creating Meaningful Moments: Facilitating opportunities for the family to create lasting memories and celebrate the child's life.

lessons.title: Financial and Legal Complexities: The Thompson Case
outline: Presenting the Thompson Case: A 65-year-old client with limited financial resources and complex legal issues related to estate planning and healthcare access.
Identifying Financial and Legal Needs: Assessing the client's financial situation, insurance coverage, and legal documents, and identifying any potential gaps or challenges.
Connecting with Resources: Linking the client with resources such as legal aid organizations, financial advisors, and government assistance programs.
Navigating Healthcare Systems: Assisting the client in navigating the healthcare system, understanding their rights, and accessing appropriate medical care.
Ethical Considerations: Maintaining confidentiality, avoiding conflicts of interest, and adhering to ethical guidelines when providing financial and legal assistance.

lessons.title: Cultural Sensitivity and End-of-Life Rituals: The Patel Case
outline: Presenting the Patel Case: An 80-year-old client from a specific cultural background with unique beliefs and practices related to death and dying.
Understanding Cultural Differences: Researching and understanding the client's cultural background, including their beliefs about death, mourning rituals, and family roles.
Respecting Cultural Preferences: Honoring the client's cultural preferences and incorporating them into the care plan, as appropriate.
Communicating with Family: Working with the family to understand their cultural expectations and facilitate communication between the client, family, and healthcare providers.
Avoiding Cultural Stereotypes: Recognizing the diversity within cultural groups and avoiding generalizations or assumptions about the client's beliefs and practices.

lessons.title: Synthesizing the PEACE Framework: A Holistic Approach to End-of-Life Doula Care
outline: Review of the PEACE Framework: Reinforcing the core principles of Presence & Perspective, Exploration & Education, Action & Advocacy, Comfort & Connection, and Embrace & Evolve.
Integrating the PEACE Framework into Practice: Applying the framework to address the multifaceted needs of clients and families facing end-of-life.
Developing Personalized Care Plans: Creating individualized care plans that reflect the client's unique values, preferences, and goals.
Ethical Considerations: Reviewing ethical guidelines and best practices for end-of-life doulas, including confidentiality, boundaries, and scope of practice.
Continuing Education and Professional Development: Emphasizing the importance of ongoing learning, self-reflection, and professional development to enhance doula skills and knowledge.

lessons.title: Navigating Ambiguous Grief and Complicated Bereavement
outline: Understanding ambiguous loss: Explore scenarios where loss is unclear or ongoing (e.g., dementia, missing persons, chronic illness).
Differentiating complicated grief from normal bereavement: Identify the diagnostic criteria and risk factors for prolonged grief disorder.
Applying the PEACE framework to support clients experiencing ambiguous loss: Focus on presence, exploration, and comfort.
Strategies for facilitating meaning-making and acceptance in the face of uncertainty.
Case Study: Support for a family dealing with a loved one in a persistent vegetative state.

lessons.title: Supporting Clients with a History of Trauma
outline: Understanding the impact of trauma on the end-of-life experience: Discuss potential triggers, emotional dysregulation, and dissociation.
Trauma-informed care principles: Emphasize safety, trustworthiness, choice, collaboration, and empowerment.
Techniques for creating a safe and supportive environment: Grounding exercises, mindfulness practices, and gentle communication.
Collaborating with mental health professionals: Recognizing when to refer clients for specialized trauma therapy.
Case Study: A client with PTSD related to past medical trauma approaching end-of-life.

lessons.title: Working with Families Experiencing Conflict
outline: Identifying common sources of family conflict during end-of-life: Inheritance disputes, differing opinions on care, unresolved past issues.
Mediation and conflict resolution skills: Active listening, empathy, and facilitating constructive dialogue.
Establishing clear communication boundaries and expectations: Helping families navigate difficult conversations.
Strategies for de-escalating tense situations and promoting understanding.
Case Study: A family struggling with disagreements about the client's wishes for medical intervention.

lessons.title: Addressing Spiritual Distress and Existential Crises
outline: Recognizing signs of spiritual distress: Questioning meaning, loss of faith, feelings of abandonment.
Exploring existential concerns: Fear of death, regret, unfinished business, legacy.
Facilitating spiritual exploration: Encouraging reflection, connection with nature, and creative expression.
Partnering with spiritual advisors and faith communities: Connecting clients with appropriate resources.
Case Study: A client questioning their life's purpose and facing profound existential anxiety.

lessons.title: Managing Ethical Dilemmas and Complex Medical Decisions
outline: Understanding common ethical dilemmas in end-of-life care: Assisted suicide, euthanasia, withholding or withdrawing treatment.
Applying ethical frameworks: Autonomy, beneficence, non-maleficence, and justice.
Facilitating informed consent and shared decision-making: Ensuring clients understand their options and potential consequences.
Navigating conflicts between patient autonomy and family wishes.
Case Study: A client with advanced dementia whose family disagrees about the appropriateness of a feeding tube.

lessons.title: Supporting Clients with Cognitive Impairment
outline: Understanding the impact of cognitive impairment on communication and decision-making.
Strategies for adapting communication techniques: Using simple language, visual aids, and nonverbal cues.
Working with surrogate decision-makers: Understanding their roles and responsibilities.
Ensuring the client's comfort and dignity despite cognitive limitations.
Case Study: Providing end-of-life care for a client with Alzheimer's disease.

lessons.title: Addressing Financial and Legal Concerns
outline: Identifying potential financial and legal challenges at the end of life: Estate planning, probate, medical debt.
Connecting clients with relevant resources: Elder law attorneys, financial advisors, and social service agencies.
Understanding the importance of advance directives and power of attorney documents.
Helping clients navigate complex bureaucratic processes.
Case Study: Assisting a client with limited financial resources to access hospice care.

lessons.title: Self-Care and Preventing Burnout in Complex Cases
outline: Recognizing the signs of burnout: Emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and reduced personal accomplishment.
Implementing self-care strategies: Mindfulness, exercise, healthy eating, and social support.
Setting boundaries with clients and families: Protecting your time and energy.
Seeking supervision and peer support: Processing difficult emotions and experiences.
Developing resilience and maintaining a healthy work-life balance.

lessons.title: Synthesizing the PEACE Framework in Practice
outline: Review of the PEACE Framework: Reinforce the core principles of Presence & Perspective, Exploration & Education, Action & Advocacy, Comfort & Connection, and Embrace & Evolve.

Identifying Key Decision Points: Explore how the PEACE framework guides decision-making at critical junctures in the end-of-life journey.
Ethical Considerations in PEACE: Discuss ethical dilemmas that may arise when implementing the PEACE framework and strategies for resolution.

lessons.title: Advanced Communication Skills: Navigating Complex Conversations
outline: Deep Dive into Non-Violent Communication (NVC): Practice advanced NVC techniques for expressing empathy, needs, and requests in challenging situations.
Facilitating Family Conflict: Strategies for mediating disagreements and fostering understanding among family members with differing opinions.
Addressing Spiritual Distress: Techniques for providing spiritual support and facilitating conversations about existential concerns and meaning-making.
Communicating with Healthcare Professionals: Effective strategies for advocating for the client's needs and wishes within the medical system.

lessons.title: Integrating Grief Support Models
outline: Comparative Analysis of Grief Models: Examine and contrast different grief models (e.g., Kübler-Ross, Dual Process Model, Meaning-Making Model) to understand their strengths and limitations.
Personalizing Grief Support: Tailoring grief support interventions based on individual client needs, cultural background, and coping styles.
Supporting Anticipatory Grief: Advanced strategies for helping clients and families cope with the emotional challenges of anticipatory grief.
Navigating Complicated Grief: Identifying and addressing risk factors for complicated grief and providing appropriate referrals.

lessons.title: Cultural Competence and Humility in End-of-Life Care
outline: Deepening Cultural Awareness: Exploring diverse cultural perspectives on death, dying, and bereavement to enhance cultural sensitivity.

Culturally Sensitive Communication: Adapting communication styles and approaches to meet the needs of clients from diverse cultural backgrounds.

lessons.title: Advanced Care Planning Facilitation
outline: Facilitating Values Clarification: Guiding clients through a process of identifying and prioritizing their values to inform advance care planning decisions.
Navigating Difficult Decisions: Supporting clients in making complex decisions about medical treatments, end-of-life care options, and legacy planning.
Documenting Advance Directives: Ensuring that advance directives are accurately documented, legally valid, and readily accessible to healthcare providers.
Promoting Shared Decision-Making: Facilitating communication and collaboration between clients, families, and healthcare professionals to ensure that care aligns with the client's wishes.

lessons.title: Self-Care and Resilience for End-of-Life Doulas
outline: Recognizing Burnout and Compassion Fatigue: Identifying the signs and symptoms of burnout and compassion fatigue in end-of-life doulas.
Developing Self-Care Strategies: Implementing proactive self-care practices to maintain emotional, physical, and spiritual well-being.
Building Resilience: Cultivating resilience through mindfulness, self-compassion, and social support.
Establishing Boundaries: Setting healthy boundaries with clients and families to prevent emotional overwhelm and maintain professional integrity.

lessons.title: Building a Sustainable Doula Practice
outline: Defining Your Niche: Identifying your unique skills, interests, and target market to create a focused doula practice.
Marketing and Networking: Developing effective marketing strategies and building relationships with key stakeholders in the end-of-life care community.
Financial Management: Understanding financial planning, budgeting, and pricing strategies for a sustainable doula practice.
Legal and Ethical Considerations: Navigating legal and ethical issues related to doula practice, including contracts, liability, and confidentiality.

lessons.title: Mentorship and Continuing Education
outline: The Importance of Mentorship: Exploring the benefits of mentorship for both mentors and mentees in the field of end-of-life doula work.

Continuing Education Opportunities: Reviewing relevant continuing education resources and professional development opportunities to enhance doula skills and knowledge.
Staying Current with Best Practices: Discussing strategies for staying up-to-date with the latest research, guidelines, and best practices in end-of-life care.

lessons.title: Evidence-Based Practices in End-of-Life Doula Care
outline: Defining evidence-based practice (EBP) and its importance in end-of-life care.

Applying EBP to doula work: integrating research findings into client care while respecting individual preferences and values.

lessons.title: The Role of Qualitative Research in Understanding End-of-Life Experiences
outline: Understanding the principles and methodologies of qualitative research (e.g., phenomenology, grounded theory, ethnography).
Recognizing the value of qualitative studies in capturing the lived experiences, perspectives, and meanings associated with dying, death, and bereavement.
Analyzing qualitative data: thematic analysis, narrative analysis, and discourse analysis.
Identifying qualitative research studies relevant to end-of-life doula practice, such as studies on grief, spiritual needs, and communication preferences.
Using qualitative findings to inform doula interventions: tailoring support to meet individual needs and preferences.

lessons.title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Doula Interventions: Quantitative Approaches
outline: Understanding basic statistical concepts: descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, and statistical significance.
Exploring quantitative research designs commonly used to evaluate doula interventions: RCTs, quasi-experimental studies, and observational studies.
Identifying key outcome measures for assessing the effectiveness of doula care: quality of life, pain management, anxiety reduction, and satisfaction with care.
Interpreting quantitative research findings: understanding effect sizes, confidence intervals, and p-values.
Applying quantitative evidence to demonstrate the value of doula services and advocate for their integration into healthcare settings.

lessons.title: Navigating Ethical Considerations in Research Related to End-of-Life Care
outline: Understanding ethical principles guiding research involving vulnerable populations: autonomy, beneficence, non-maleficence, and justice.
Addressing informed consent in end-of-life research: ensuring participants understand the risks and benefits of participation and have the capacity to consent.
Protecting participant privacy and confidentiality: safeguarding sensitive information and maintaining anonymity.
Recognizing potential conflicts of interest in research: disclosing affiliations and biases that may influence research findings.
Promoting ethical conduct in doula-led research: adhering to ethical guidelines and seeking guidance from institutional review boards (IRBs).

lessons.title: Research on Grief and Bereavement: Implications for Doula Support
outline: Exploring different models of grief: stage-based models, attachment theory, and meaning-making perspectives.
Understanding the distinction between normal grief, complicated grief, and disenfranchised grief.
Reviewing research on factors that influence the grieving process: personality, social support, cultural norms, and circumstances of death.
Identifying evidence-based interventions for supporting bereaved individuals: grief counseling, support groups, and expressive therapies.
Applying research findings to provide compassionate and effective grief support to clients and their families, in alignment with the 'E' (Embrace & Evolve) within the PEACE framework.

lessons.title: Spirituality and End-of-Life: Examining the Evidence
outline: Defining spirituality and its role in end-of-life care: meaning, purpose, connection, and transcendence.
Exploring research on the relationship between spirituality and well-being in the face of death: hope, resilience, and quality of life.
Identifying spiritual assessment tools and interventions: spiritual history taking, guided meditation, and ritual facilitation.
Reviewing studies on the impact of spiritual care on end-of-life outcomes: pain management, anxiety reduction, and spiritual growth.
Integrating spiritual considerations into doula practice: respecting diverse beliefs, facilitating spiritual exploration, and connecting clients with spiritual resources.

lessons.title: The Evidence Base for Complementary and Integrative Therapies in Palliative Care
outline: Defining complementary and integrative therapies (CITs) and their role in palliative care: acupuncture, massage therapy, aromatherapy, music therapy, and art therapy.

Understanding the mechanisms of action of CITs: physiological, psychological, and spiritual effects.
Identifying contraindications and safety considerations for CITs: potential risks and side effects.
Integrating CITs into doula practice: offering evidence-based options, collaborating with licensed practitioners, and respecting client preferences.

lessons.title: Staying Current: Accessing and Evaluating New Research in End-of-Life Care
outline: Identifying reliable sources of new research findings: peer-reviewed journals, professional conferences, and online databases.
Developing strategies for critically appraising research articles: assessing study design, sample size, statistical analysis, and limitations.
Participating in continuing education activities: attending workshops, webinars, and conferences to stay updated on the latest evidence.
Networking with other professionals in the field: sharing research findings and best practices with colleagues.
Advocating for evidence-based practice in end-of-life care: promoting the use of research findings to improve client outcomes and advance the doula profession.

lessons.title: Introduction to Comprehensive End-of-Life Assessment

Ethical considerations in assessment: Confidentiality, informed consent, and respecting client autonomy.
The role of assessment in informing doula interventions and care planning, aligning with the PEACE Framework.
Distinguishing between assessment, diagnosis, and medical evaluation: Understanding the doula's scope of practice.
Review of key principles from Module 15: L1 Deep Dive, emphasizing the importance of holistic care.

lessons.title: Physical and Practical Assessment Tools
outline: Using the Edmonton Symptom Assessment System (ESAS) to identify and track physical symptoms (pain, fatigue, nausea, etc.).

Reviewing advance care planning documents: Identifying gaps and facilitating completion or updates, if desired.
Utilizing environmental assessment checklists to ensure safety and comfort within the client's living space.

lessons.title: Emotional and Psychological Assessment Tools
outline: Employing the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) as a screening tool for anxiety and depression.
Using open-ended questions and active listening techniques to explore feelings of grief, loss, and fear.
Assessing coping mechanisms and resilience through observation and client self-reporting.
Identifying signs of caregiver burnout and providing support and resources to family members.

lessons.title: Spiritual and Existential Assessment Tools

lessons.title: Documentation and Communication of Assessment Findings

Avoiding medical jargon and using clear, concise language when documenting and communicating assessment results.

lessons.title: Cultural Considerations in Assessment

Adapting assessment tools and techniques to be culturally sensitive and appropriate.
Understanding the role of family and community in end-of-life care within different cultures.

Reflecting on personal biases and assumptions that may influence assessment findings.

lessons.title: Principles of Comprehensive End-of-Life Treatment Planning

lessons.title: Assessment Tools and Techniques for Treatment Planning

Advanced interviewing techniques to elicit deeper insights into client's fears, hopes, and spiritual beliefs.
Identifying potential barriers to effective treatment and strategies for overcoming them.
Documenting assessment findings and using them to create a comprehensive client profile.

lessons.title: Integrating the PEACE Framework™ into Treatment Planning: Presence, Exploration, and Action

lessons.title: Integrating the PEACE Framework™ into Treatment Planning: Comfort and Embrace
outline: Enhancing 'Comfort & Connection' (C): Implementing strategies for pain management, symptom relief, and fostering meaningful connections with loved ones.

lessons.title: Developing SMART End-of-Life Treatment Goals
outline: Defining SMART goals (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) in the context of end-of-life care.

lessons.title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Treatment Plans

lessons.title: Defining Ethical Practice in End-of-Life Doula Work

lessons.title: Navigating Scope of Practice

lessons.title: Confidentiality and Privacy
