Utilizing technology ethically: Ensuring secure communication and data storage when using electronic devices and platforms.

lessons.title: Informed Consent and Decision-Making
outline: Defining informed consent and its importance in end-of-life care.
Understanding the elements of valid informed consent: voluntariness, capacity, information, and comprehension.
Providing clients with clear and unbiased information about their options, risks, and benefits.
Supporting clients in making autonomous decisions that align with their values and wishes.
Addressing situations where the client's capacity to make decisions is impaired and navigating surrogate decision-making processes.

lessons.title: Conflicts of Interest and Dual Relationships
outline: Identifying potential conflicts of interest that may arise in end-of-life doula work (e.g., financial interests, personal relationships).
Avoiding dual relationships that could compromise objectivity or exploit the client's vulnerability.
Establishing clear boundaries and professional distance to maintain ethical integrity.
Discussing strategies for managing conflicts of interest and disclosing potential biases.
Case study analysis: Examining scenarios where conflicts of interest or dual relationships may occur and determining appropriate courses of action.

lessons.title: Cultural Sensitivity and Humility
outline: Recognizing the diversity of cultural beliefs, values, and practices related to death and dying.
Cultivating cultural humility: Approaching each client with openness, respect, and a willingness to learn.
Avoiding cultural stereotypes and biases that could negatively impact care.
Seeking consultation and collaboration with cultural brokers or experts when necessary.
Adapting doula practices to align with the client's cultural preferences and traditions.
Addressing potential conflicts between cultural practices and legal or ethical obligations.

lessons.title: Ethical Considerations in Specific Scenarios
outline: Ethical considerations when working with clients who are considering medical aid in dying (MAID).
Navigating ethical dilemmas related to withholding or withdrawing life-sustaining treatment.
Addressing ethical concerns related to pain management and palliative care.
Ethical considerations when working with clients who have dementia or other cognitive impairments.
Supporting clients who are experiencing spiritual or existential distress.
Providing ethical guidance to family members and caregivers who are facing difficult decisions.

lessons.title: Self-Care and Ethical Sustainability
outline: Recognizing the emotional and psychological demands of end-of-life doula work.
Developing self-care strategies to prevent burnout and maintain well-being.
Seeking supervision, mentorship, or peer support to process challenging experiences and ethical dilemmas.
Establishing healthy boundaries between personal and professional life.
Committing to ongoing professional development and ethical reflection.
Understanding vicarious trauma and compassion fatigue; implementing strategies for prevention and management.

lessons.title: Advanced Communication Skills: Beyond Active Listening
outline: Explore the nuances of non-violent communication (NVC) in end-of-life care, including identifying feelings and needs, making requests, and practicing empathy in challenging conversations.
Discuss techniques for navigating difficult conversations related to treatment refusal, palliative sedation, and end-of-life planning with diverse cultural and belief systems.
Examine strategies for communicating with clients experiencing cognitive decline or communication impairments, utilizing visual aids, sensory stimulation, and alternative communication methods.
Analyze the role of narrative therapy in helping clients reframe their life stories and find meaning in the face of mortality, including techniques for eliciting and documenting personal narratives.
Practice advanced questioning techniques, such as the Socratic method, to help clients explore their values, beliefs, and fears related to death and dying.

lessons.title: Advanced Pain and Symptom Management Support
outline: Review pharmacological and non-pharmacological approaches to pain management, emphasizing the importance of personalized care and collaboration with the healthcare team.
Discuss advanced techniques for managing common end-of-life symptoms such as dyspnea, nausea, anxiety, and delirium, including complementary therapies like aromatherapy, massage, and music therapy.
Explore the role of medical cannabis in palliative care, including different formulations, routes of administration, and potential benefits and risks, adhering to legal and ethical considerations.
Examine the ethical considerations surrounding palliative sedation, including indications, contraindications, and the importance of informed consent and shared decision-making.
Discuss strategies for supporting families in managing their loved one's symptoms and providing comfort care at home, including practical tips and resources.

lessons.title: Spiritual Care: Deepening the Connection
outline: Explore advanced techniques for providing spiritual support to clients from diverse religious, cultural, and philosophical backgrounds, including those who are non-religious or spiritual but not religious.
Discuss the role of mindfulness and meditation in cultivating inner peace and reducing suffering for clients facing death, including guided meditation practices and breathwork techniques.
Examine the use of ritual and ceremony in creating meaningful experiences and fostering closure for clients and their families, including personalized rituals and memorial services.
Analyze the concept of spiritual pain and explore strategies for addressing existential questions, feelings of meaninglessness, and unresolved conflicts at the end of life.
Discuss the importance of self-care for end-of-life doulas in maintaining their own spiritual well-being and preventing burnout.

lessons.title: Grief and Bereavement: Advanced Support Strategies
outline: Explore advanced grief theories, including complicated grief and disenfranchised grief, and discuss strategies for identifying and supporting individuals experiencing these challenges.
Examine the role of creative arts therapies, such as art, music, and writing, in facilitating emotional expression and processing grief for clients and their families.
Discuss techniques for supporting children and adolescents who are grieving the loss of a loved one, including age-appropriate communication strategies and creative activities.
Analyze the impact of sudden or traumatic loss on grief and bereavement, and explore strategies for providing specialized support to individuals and families affected by these events.
Discuss the importance of cultural sensitivity in grief support, including understanding diverse grieving rituals and beliefs, and providing culturally appropriate resources.

lessons.title: Navigating Ethical Dilemmas: Advanced Scenarios
outline: Analyze complex ethical dilemmas that may arise in end-of-life care, such as physician-assisted suicide, euthanasia, and the use of experimental treatments, considering diverse perspectives and legal frameworks.
Discuss the principles of autonomy, beneficence, non-maleficence, and justice in the context of end-of-life decision-making, and explore strategies for resolving ethical conflicts.
Examine the role of ethics committees in healthcare settings and discuss how to access and utilize these resources when facing ethical challenges.
Explore the ethical considerations surrounding cultural and religious beliefs that may conflict with conventional medical practices, and discuss strategies for promoting culturally sensitive care.
Discuss the importance of documentation and communication in ethical decision-making, and explore strategies for ensuring transparency and accountability in practice.

lessons.title: Advanced Advocacy Skills: Empowering Client Choice
outline: Explore advanced techniques for advocating for clients' rights and preferences in healthcare settings, including navigating complex bureaucratic systems and challenging discriminatory practices.
Discuss the role of legal documents, such as advance directives, powers of attorney, and wills, in ensuring clients' wishes are honored, and provide guidance on completing these documents.
Examine the importance of cultural humility in advocacy, including understanding diverse cultural beliefs and values related to death and dying, and tailoring advocacy strategies accordingly.
Analyze the power dynamics that may exist between clients, families, and healthcare providers, and explore strategies for empowering clients to assert their autonomy.
Discuss the role of community resources in supporting clients' end-of-life wishes, including hospice organizations, palliative care programs, and legal aid services.

lessons.title: Building Collaborative Relationships: Advanced Teamwork
outline: Explore advanced strategies for building and maintaining collaborative relationships with healthcare professionals, including physicians, nurses, social workers, and chaplains.
Discuss the importance of interdisciplinary communication in providing holistic end-of-life care, and explore techniques for facilitating effective team meetings and case conferences.
Examine the role of conflict resolution in addressing disagreements and misunderstandings among team members, and explore strategies for promoting respectful and constructive dialogue.

Analyze the benefits of shared decision-making in end-of-life care, and explore techniques for facilitating collaborative decision-making processes that involve clients, families, and healthcare providers.
Discuss the importance of professional boundaries in maintaining ethical and effective relationships with clients, families, and colleagues.

lessons.title: Integrating the PEACE Framework™: Advanced Application
outline: Review the PEACE Framework™ and its application in end-of-life doula practice, emphasizing the interconnectedness of presence, exploration, action, comfort, and embrace.
Apply the PEACE Framework™ to complex case studies involving diverse clients with unique needs and challenges, demonstrating advanced problem-solving and critical thinking skills.
Develop personalized intervention plans for clients based on the PEACE Framework™, incorporating advanced techniques in communication, symptom management, spiritual care, grief support, and advocacy.
Reflect on personal strengths and areas for growth in applying the PEACE Framework™, and identify strategies for continuous professional development.
Discuss the importance of ethical considerations and self-care in maintaining a sustainable and fulfilling end-of-life doula practice while utilizing the PEACE Framework™.

lessons.title: Advanced Communication Techniques: Beyond Active Listening
outline: Mastering the Art of Reflective Inquiry: Probing deeper into client values and beliefs without imposing personal biases.
Non-Verbal Communication Mastery: Interpreting nuanced body language and adapting communication styles for diverse populations.
Conflict Resolution and Mediation: Facilitating difficult conversations between family members regarding end-of-life decisions, using the PEACE framework as a guide.
Crisis Communication: Responding effectively to urgent emotional needs and providing immediate support during times of heightened stress and grief.
Case Study: Navigating a complex family dynamic where conflicting beliefs about medical intervention create tension and distress for the client.

lessons.title: Ethical Dilemmas and Decision-Making Frameworks
outline: In-Depth Analysis of Ethical Principles: Autonomy, Beneficence, Non-Maleficence, and Justice in end-of-life care, with real-world examples.
Navigating Complex Ethical Scenarios: Addressing issues such as assisted dying, palliative sedation, and conflicts of interest.
Ethical Decision-Making Models: Applying structured frameworks to analyze ethical dilemmas and arrive at well-reasoned solutions.
Legal Considerations and Compliance: Understanding relevant laws and regulations pertaining to end-of-life care, including advance directives and power of attorney.
Case Study: An end-of-life doula faces an ethical dilemma when a client requests assistance that falls outside the scope of legal and ethical practice.

lessons.title: Spiritual Care and Existential Support: Deepening the Connection
outline: Advanced Techniques for Spiritual Assessment: Identifying and addressing profound spiritual needs and existential concerns.
Facilitating Meaning-Making and Legacy Work: Guiding clients in reflecting on their lives, values, and contributions to create a lasting legacy.
Supporting Diverse Belief Systems: Providing culturally sensitive and respectful spiritual care to individuals from various religious and non-religious backgrounds.
Addressing Existential Distress: Helping clients cope with feelings of meaninglessness, isolation, and fear of the unknown.
Case Study: A client grappling with profound regret and unresolved grief seeks guidance in finding peace and meaning at the end of life.

lessons.title: Advanced Grief and Bereavement Support: Beyond the Basics
outline: Understanding Complicated Grief: Identifying and addressing factors that contribute to prolonged and debilitating grief responses.
Trauma-Informed Grief Support: Providing sensitive and effective support to individuals who have experienced traumatic loss.
Facilitating Grief Rituals and Memorials: Creating meaningful ceremonies and tributes to honor the deceased and support the grieving process.
Supporting Families Through Anticipatory Grief: Helping loved ones cope with the emotional challenges of witnessing a loved one's decline.
Case Study: Supporting a family experiencing complicated grief following the sudden and unexpected death of a young adult.

lessons.title: Building and Managing a Thriving End-of-Life Doula Practice
outline: Advanced Marketing and Networking Strategies: Reaching target audiences and building strong professional relationships.
Financial Management and Business Planning: Developing a sustainable business model and managing finances effectively.
Legal and Ethical Considerations for Business Practices: Ensuring compliance with relevant laws and regulations.
Client Intake and Assessment: Implementing comprehensive processes for gathering information and assessing client needs.
Case Study: An end-of-life doula successfully builds a thriving practice by leveraging effective marketing strategies and providing exceptional client care.

lessons.title: Collaborative Care and Interprofessional Communication
outline: Effective Communication with Healthcare Professionals: Building rapport and advocating for client needs within the healthcare system.
Collaborating with Hospice and Palliative Care Teams: Understanding the roles and responsibilities of different team members.
Navigating Complex Healthcare Systems: Advocating for client access to appropriate resources and services.
Conflict Resolution in Interprofessional Settings: Addressing disagreements and misunderstandings constructively.
Case Study: An end-of-life doula effectively collaborates with a hospice team to provide comprehensive and holistic care to a client with advanced cancer.

lessons.title: Self-Care and Resilience for the End-of-Life Doula
outline: Recognizing and Addressing Compassion Fatigue: Identifying signs of burnout and implementing strategies for self-care.
Developing Resilience Strategies: Building emotional and psychological strength to cope with the challenges of end-of-life care.
Setting Healthy Boundaries: Establishing clear limits to protect personal well-being and prevent burnout.
Seeking Support and Supervision: Utilizing peer support and professional supervision to process emotions and maintain ethical practice.
Mindfulness and Self-Compassion Practices: Cultivating inner peace and resilience through mindfulness and self-compassion techniques.

lessons.title: The PEACE Framework™ in Advanced Practice: Synthesis and Application
outline: Applying the PEACE Framework™ to Complex Case Studies: Integrating all elements of the framework to provide holistic and client-centered care in challenging situations.
Adapting the PEACE Framework™ for Diverse Populations: Tailoring the framework to meet the unique needs of individuals from various cultural, religious, and socioeconomic backgrounds.
Using the PEACE Framework™ for Self-Reflection and Professional Development: Applying the framework to personal growth and ongoing learning.
Integrating Research and Evidence into PEACE Framework™ Application: Staying current with best practices and incorporating evidence-based approaches into doula work.

Final Case Study: A master practitioner utilizes the PEACE framework to guide a client and their family through a particularly difficult and emotionally charged end-of-life journey, demonstrating exceptional skill and compassion.

lessons.title: The Role of Supervision in End-of-Life Doula Practice
outline: Defining supervision in the context of end-of-life doula work: differentiating it from mentorship and consultation.
Ethical considerations and professional boundaries within the supervisory relationship, referencing relevant codes of conduct.
Benefits of supervision for doulas: improved practice, reduced burnout, enhanced self-awareness, and increased confidence.
Exploring different models of supervision: individual, group, peer supervision, and organizational supervision.
Case Study: A doula experiencing secondary trauma seeks supervision to process their emotional response to a challenging client case.

lessons.title: Finding and Selecting a Supervisor
outline: Identifying the qualities of an effective supervisor: experience, expertise, communication skills, and ethical alignment.
Strategies for finding qualified supervisors: professional organizations, online directories, referrals from colleagues.
Conducting initial interviews with potential supervisors: questions to ask, expectations to clarify, and fees to discuss.
Establishing a supervision agreement: defining roles, responsibilities, frequency, duration, and confidentiality.
Assessing the supervisor-doula fit: considering personality, learning styles, and supervisory approaches.

lessons.title: Core Competencies for End-of-Life Doula Supervisors
outline: Deepening understanding of the PEACE Framework™ within the supervisory context, focusing on how each element (Presence, Exploration, Action, Comfort, Embrace) informs effective support of doulas.
Providing constructive feedback: techniques for delivering both positive reinforcement and areas for improvement.
Facilitating self-reflection: helping doulas explore their values, biases, and emotional responses to client work.
Addressing ethical dilemmas: guiding doulas through complex ethical situations and promoting ethical decision-making.
Supporting professional development: identifying learning opportunities and resources to enhance doula skills and knowledge.

lessons.title: The Supervision Process: Techniques and Strategies
outline: Structuring supervision sessions: establishing an agenda, setting goals, and prioritizing topics.
Using different supervision techniques: case consultation, role-playing, reflective practice, and journaling.
Addressing transference and countertransference: recognizing and managing emotional dynamics in the doula-client relationship.
Managing conflict and resistance in supervision: strategies for addressing difficult conversations and promoting open communication.
Case Study: A supervisor helps a doula navigate a conflict with a family member who disagrees with the client's end-of-life wishes.

lessons.title: Mentoring in End-of-Life Doula Practice
outline: Differentiating mentoring from supervision: focusing on guidance, support, and professional development rather than direct oversight.
Identifying the benefits of mentoring for new and experienced doulas: knowledge transfer, skill development, and career advancement.
Exploring different mentoring models: formal and informal mentoring, peer mentoring, and group mentoring.
Developing a mentoring relationship: establishing trust, setting goals, and maintaining regular communication.
Applying the PEACE Framework™ principles to mentoring relationships, emphasizing the 'Embrace & Evolve' aspect in fostering continuous growth.

lessons.title: Becoming a Mentor: Skills and Qualities
outline: Key qualities of an effective mentor: empathy, active listening, patience, and a willingness to share knowledge and experience.
Developing mentoring skills: providing guidance, offering support, and challenging mentees to grow.
Facilitating mentee self-assessment: helping mentees identify their strengths, weaknesses, and areas for development.
Providing feedback and encouragement: offering constructive criticism and celebrating mentee successes.
Addressing challenges in the mentoring relationship: managing expectations, resolving conflicts, and maintaining boundaries.

lessons.title: Ethical and Legal Considerations in Supervision and Mentoring
outline: Maintaining confidentiality: protecting client information and respecting doula privacy.
Addressing conflicts of interest: identifying and managing potential conflicts between supervisory/mentoring roles and other professional relationships.
Ensuring competence: providing supervision and mentoring within the scope of one's own expertise and qualifications.
Documenting supervision and mentoring activities: maintaining records of sessions, agreements, and progress.
Understanding legal liabilities: being aware of potential legal risks associated with supervision and mentoring responsibilities.

lessons.title: Building a Sustainable Supervision and Mentoring Practice
outline: Developing a business plan for offering supervision and mentoring services: defining target audience, setting fees, and marketing services.
Creating a professional development plan for supervisors and mentors: staying up-to-date on best practices, attending training, and seeking supervision.
Networking with other professionals: building relationships with potential referral sources and collaborators.
Evaluating the effectiveness of supervision and mentoring programs: collecting feedback from doulas and mentees, and making adjustments as needed.
Advocating for the importance of supervision and mentoring in the end-of-life doula field: promoting professional standards and ethical practice.

lessons.title: Identifying Community Needs and Target Populations
outline: Conducting a needs assessment: Analyzing demographic data, existing services, and gaps in end-of-life care within the community.

Defining specific target populations: Focusing on underserved groups such as LGBTQ+ individuals, veterans, individuals experiencing homelessness, or those with specific cultural or religious backgrounds.
Using surveys, focus groups, and interviews to gather qualitative and quantitative data on community needs and preferences.
Analyzing findings to identify key program priorities and potential partnerships with existing organizations.
Ethical considerations in needs assessment: ensuring inclusivity, confidentiality, and cultural sensitivity.

lessons.title: Defining Program Goals, Objectives, and Scope
outline: Developing SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound) goals and objectives for the end-of-life doula program.
Defining the scope of services offered: including emotional support, legacy work, advance care planning assistance, vigil support, and grief support.
Determining eligibility criteria for clients participating in the program: considering factors such as diagnosis, prognosis, and financial need.
Establishing clear program policies and procedures: addressing issues such as confidentiality, informed consent, and conflict resolution.
Creating a mission statement that reflects the program's values and commitment to providing compassionate end-of-life care.

lessons.title: Developing a Comprehensive Program Curriculum
outline: Designing a curriculum that aligns with the PEACE Framework™ and incorporates best practices in end-of-life care.
Including modules on communication skills, cultural sensitivity, ethical considerations, grief and bereavement, and self-care for doulas.
Integrating experiential learning activities such as role-playing, case studies, and simulations to enhance doula skills and confidence.
Creating training materials that are accessible, engaging, and culturally appropriate for diverse learners.
Establishing a process for ongoing curriculum evaluation and revision based on feedback from doulas, clients, and stakeholders.

lessons.title: Recruiting, Training, and Supervising End-of-Life Doulas
outline: Developing a recruitment strategy to attract qualified and compassionate individuals to the end-of-life doula program.
Implementing a rigorous screening process: including interviews, background checks, and reference checks to ensure doulas meet program standards.
Providing comprehensive training and ongoing professional development opportunities for doulas.
Establishing a supervision structure: including regular meetings with experienced mentors or supervisors to provide guidance and support.
Developing performance evaluation tools to assess doula competence and identify areas for improvement.

lessons.title: Building Partnerships and Securing Funding
outline: Identifying potential partners: including hospitals, hospices, community organizations, and faith-based institutions.
Developing collaborative relationships with partners: to expand program reach and access to resources.
Exploring funding opportunities: including grants, donations, and fee-for-service models.
Writing compelling grant proposals: that articulate the program's mission, goals, and impact.
Developing a fundraising plan: to ensure the long-term financial sustainability of the end-of-life doula program.

lessons.title: Marketing and Outreach Strategies
outline: Developing a marketing plan to raise awareness of the end-of-life doula program within the community.
Creating marketing materials: including brochures, flyers, and website content that highlight the program's benefits and services.
Utilizing social media platforms: to reach target audiences and share information about end-of-life care.
Conducting outreach activities: such as presentations, workshops, and community events to educate the public about the role of end-of-life doulas.
Establishing relationships with media outlets: to generate positive press coverage for the program.

lessons.title: Program Evaluation and Quality Improvement
outline: Developing a program evaluation plan: to assess the effectiveness of the end-of-life doula program in achieving its goals and objectives.
Collecting data on program outcomes: including client satisfaction, quality of life, and caregiver burden.
Analyzing data to identify areas for program improvement and inform decision-making.
Implementing quality improvement initiatives: based on evaluation findings to enhance program effectiveness and client outcomes.
Using evaluation results to demonstrate program impact to funders and stakeholders.

lessons.title: Sustainability and Scalability of Programs
outline: Creating a sustainability plan to ensure the long-term viability of the end-of-life doula program.
Diversifying funding sources and building a strong donor base.
Developing a succession plan to ensure leadership continuity.
Exploring opportunities to scale the program to reach more clients and communities.
Creating a replicable program model that can be adapted to different settings and populations.
Developing a train-the-trainer program to expand the pool of qualified end-of-life doulas.

lessons.title: Supporting Clients with Dementia and Cognitive Decline
outline: Understanding the unique challenges of end-of-life care for individuals with dementia, focusing on communication difficulties and fluctuating levels of awareness.
Adapting the PEACE Framework™ to meet the specific needs of clients with cognitive impairment, emphasizing non-verbal communication and sensory-based comfort measures.
Ethical considerations in end-of-life decision-making for clients with dementia, including advance directives and surrogate decision-makers.
Strategies for managing common dementia-related symptoms at the end of life, such as agitation, anxiety, and pain, using person-centered approaches.
Case Study: Mrs. Eleanor, 88, with advanced Alzheimer's. Focusing on sensory stimulation, familiar music, and creating a calming environment.

lessons.title: Navigating Pediatric End-of-Life Care
outline: Addressing the emotional and spiritual needs of children facing life-limiting illnesses and their families, including siblings.
Communicating with children about death and dying in age-appropriate ways, using play therapy, art, and storytelling.
Collaborating with pediatric palliative care teams to provide holistic support, including pain management, symptom control, and psychosocial care.
Supporting parents and caregivers in making difficult decisions about their child's care, including end-of-life planning and legacy building.
Understanding the legal and ethical considerations specific to pediatric end-of-life care, such as parental rights and informed consent.
Case Study: 10-year-old Michael with terminal cancer. Focusing on legacy building through creating a memory box and recording messages for his family.

lessons.title: End-of-Life Doula Support in Correctional Facilities
outline: Understanding the unique challenges and barriers to end-of-life care in correctional settings, including limited resources and security protocols.
Advocating for compassionate and dignified end-of-life care for incarcerated individuals, ensuring access to palliative care and hospice services.
Providing emotional and spiritual support to inmates facing death, addressing issues of isolation, guilt, and remorse.
Navigating the legal and ethical considerations specific to end-of-life care in correctional facilities, including confidentiality and informed consent.
Collaborating with correctional staff, healthcare providers, and community organizations to improve end-of-life care for incarcerated individuals.
Case Study: Mr. Jones, 62, incarcerated with terminal heart failure. Focusing on facilitating communication with estranged family and spiritual support.

lessons.title: Supporting Veterans at the End of Life
outline: Understanding the unique experiences and needs of veterans facing end-of-life, including post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), moral injury, and military-related health conditions.
Providing culturally sensitive care that honors veterans' service and sacrifice, addressing issues of identity, purpose, and legacy.
Collaborating with the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and other veteran-serving organizations to ensure access to comprehensive end-of-life care services.
Addressing the emotional and spiritual needs of veterans, including reconciliation, forgiveness, and finding meaning in their military experiences.
Understanding the specific benefits and resources available to veterans and their families at the end of life, such as hospice care, burial benefits, and survivor benefits.
Case Study: Mr. Smith, 75, a Vietnam War veteran with PTSD and terminal lung cancer. Focusing on addressing trauma through guided imagery and connecting with veteran support groups.

lessons.title: Working with Clients with HIV/AIDS in the Modern Era
outline: Understanding the evolving landscape of HIV/AIDS and its impact on end-of-life care, including the challenges of aging with HIV and managing comorbidities.
Addressing the stigma and discrimination faced by individuals with HIV/AIDS at the end of life, promoting acceptance, compassion, and dignity.
Providing culturally sensitive care that respects the diverse experiences and identities of individuals with HIV/AIDS, including LGBTQ+ individuals and marginalized communities.
Collaborating with HIV/AIDS service organizations and healthcare providers to ensure access to comprehensive end-of-life care services, including palliative care and hospice.
Addressing the emotional and spiritual needs of individuals with HIV/AIDS, including issues of isolation, grief, and finding meaning in their lives.
Case Study: Mr. Rodriguez, 60, living with HIV and facing end-stage renal disease. Focusing on addressing social isolation and connecting him with LGBTQ+ affirming resources.

lessons.title: End-of-Life Doula Support for Individuals Experiencing Homelessness
outline: Understanding the unique challenges and barriers to end-of-life care for individuals experiencing homelessness, including lack of access to healthcare, unstable housing, and social isolation.
Advocating for compassionate and dignified end-of-life care for homeless individuals, ensuring access to palliative care, hospice services, and safe and stable environments.
Providing emotional and practical support to homeless individuals facing death, addressing issues of poverty, trauma, and mental health.
Collaborating with homeless service organizations, healthcare providers, and community organizations to improve end-of-life care for homeless individuals.
Navigating the legal and ethical considerations specific to end-of-life care for homeless individuals, including guardianship and advance directives.
Case Study: Ms. Evans, 55, experiencing homelessness with terminal liver disease. Focusing on finding stable housing for her final days and connecting her with supportive services.

lessons.title: Supporting Clients with Substance Use Disorders at the End of Life
outline: Understanding the complexities of providing end-of-life care for individuals with substance use disorders, including managing withdrawal symptoms, addressing addiction-related health complications, and navigating stigma.
Collaborating with addiction specialists and healthcare providers to develop comprehensive care plans that address both the physical and psychological needs of clients with substance use disorders.
Providing emotional and spiritual support to clients and their families, addressing issues of guilt, shame, and strained relationships.
Advocating for harm reduction strategies and compassionate pain management approaches that respect the client's autonomy and minimize potential for relapse.
Exploring the impact of substance use on advance care planning and decision-making, and facilitating open communication between clients, families, and healthcare providers.
Case Study: Mr. Davis, 48, with a history of opioid addiction and terminal cancer. Focusing on pain management strategies that minimize risk of relapse and addressing his feelings of guilt and shame.

lessons.title: Integrating Cultural Humility in Specialized End-of-Life Care
outline: Defining and applying the principles of cultural humility in end-of-life doula practice, moving beyond cultural competence to lifelong learning and self-reflection.
Identifying potential cultural biases and assumptions that may impact the care provided to clients from diverse backgrounds, and developing strategies for addressing these biases.
Exploring the role of language, religion, spirituality, and family dynamics in shaping end-of-life experiences across different cultures.
Collaborating with cultural brokers and community leaders to gain a deeper understanding of the specific needs and preferences of diverse client populations.
Adapting the PEACE Framework™ to incorporate culturally sensitive communication techniques and rituals that honor the client's values and beliefs.
Case Study: A family from a culture where death is a taboo subject. Focusing on culturally sensitive communication and respecting their traditions around mourning.

lessons.title: Rapidly Declining Clients: Recognizing and Responding
outline: Identifying signs of rapid decline: Changes in breathing, cognitive function, and overall physical condition. Differentiating normal end-of-life progression from crisis.
Implementing immediate comfort measures: Administering medications (if authorized), positioning for comfort, and managing pain and agitation.
Communicating effectively with the family and medical team: Providing clear, concise updates on the client's condition and advocating for their wishes.
Applying the PEACE Framework in crisis: Prioritizing Presence & Perspective (understanding immediate needs), and swiftly moving to Action & Advocacy (ensuring wishes are honored).

lessons.title: Managing Agitation and Delirium at End-of-Life
outline: Differentiating between agitation, delirium, and pain: Understanding the underlying causes and triggers for each condition.
Non-pharmacological interventions for agitation and delirium: Environmental modifications, sensory stimulation/reduction, and reality orientation techniques.
Working with the medical team for pharmacological management: Understanding common medications used to treat agitation and delirium, and their potential side effects.
Addressing family distress related to client agitation: Providing education, support, and coping strategies for family members witnessing these symptoms.
Case Study: A client experiencing terminal delirium, and the doula's role in advocating for appropriate interventions and family support.

lessons.title: Navigating Suicidal Ideation in Terminally Ill Clients
outline: Understanding the complexities of suicidal ideation in the context of terminal illness: Differentiating between a desire for hastened death and clinical depression.
Assessing the client's risk for suicide: Identifying warning signs, and understanding the legal and ethical considerations involved.
Implementing safety measures: Removing potential hazards, and ensuring constant supervision if necessary.
Collaborating with mental health professionals: Connecting the client with appropriate resources for counseling and support.
Documenting suicidal ideation and interventions: Maintaining accurate records of all assessments, interventions, and communication with the medical team.
Ethical considerations: Balancing client autonomy with the duty to prevent harm; understanding the legal nuances of assisted suicide versus palliative sedation.

lessons.title: Sudden or Traumatic Death: Supporting the Bereaved
outline: Understanding the unique grief responses associated with sudden or traumatic death: Shock, disbelief, guilt, and complicated grief.
Providing immediate support to the bereaved: Active listening, validation of feelings, and practical assistance with funeral arrangements.
Facilitating memorialization and rituals: Creating meaningful ways to honor the deceased and promote healing.
Connecting the bereaved with specialized grief resources: Support groups, individual therapy, and crisis intervention services.
Self-care strategies for doulas: Processing personal emotions and preventing burnout after supporting families through traumatic loss.

lessons.title: Ethical Dilemmas in End-of-Life Care: Case-Based Analysis
outline: Analyzing complex ethical dilemmas: Using case studies to explore issues such as refusal of treatment, requests for hastened death, and conflicts between family members.
Applying ethical frameworks to decision-making: Autonomy, beneficence, non-maleficence, and justice.
Facilitating ethical discussions: Helping clients and families clarify their values and make informed decisions.
Understanding the role of ethics committees: When and how to access ethics consultations in healthcare settings.
Legal considerations: Understanding relevant laws and regulations related to end-of-life care, including advance directives and physician orders for life-sustaining treatment (POLST).

lessons.title: Working with Clients with Dementia at End-of-Life
outline: Understanding the unique challenges of end-of-life care for clients with dementia: Communication difficulties, cognitive impairment, and fluctuating levels of awareness.
Adapting communication techniques: Using non-verbal cues, simplified language, and sensory stimulation to connect with clients.
Managing behavioral symptoms: Addressing agitation, wandering, and resistance to care with compassion and understanding.
Supporting family caregivers: Providing education, respite care, and emotional support to family members caring for a loved one with dementia.
Advance care planning considerations: Emphasizing the importance of early advance care planning, and addressing the challenges of surrogate decision-making.

lessons.title: Pediatric End-of-Life Care: Unique Considerations

outline: Developing a comprehensive business plan that outlines target market, services offered, pricing strategies, and marketing initiatives.
Strategies for building a strong professional brand and establishing credibility as a certified end-of-life doula.
Effective marketing techniques for reaching potential clients, including networking, social media, website optimization, and community outreach.
Guidance on creating professional marketing materials, such as brochures, business cards, and online profiles.
Legal and financial considerations for operating an end-of-life doula business, including insurance, contracts, and tax requirements.

lessons.title: Advanced Resource Navigation & Collaboration
outline: Identification and utilization of advanced resources for clients with complex needs, including specialized palliative care services, hospice programs, and grief support groups.
Strategies for building collaborative relationships with healthcare professionals, social workers, and other community partners.
Advocacy techniques for ensuring clients receive appropriate and timely access to needed resources and services.
Navigation of complex healthcare systems and insurance processes to maximize client benefits and access to care.
Development of a comprehensive resource directory for end-of-life doulas in their local community.

lessons.title: Self-Care & Resilience Strategies for Advanced Practitioners
outline: Exploration of advanced self-care techniques for managing the emotional and physical demands of end-of-life doula work.
Strategies for preventing burnout, compassion fatigue, and vicarious trauma through mindfulness, boundary setting, and stress management.
The importance of ongoing supervision, peer support, and professional development for maintaining well-being and competence.
Techniques for cultivating resilience and finding meaning in the face of death and loss.
Development of a personalized self-care plan to promote long-term sustainability in the profession.

lessons.title: Final Review & Exam Preparation
outline: Comprehensive review of key concepts, principles, and skills covered throughout the certification program.
Practice questions and mock exams to assess knowledge and identify areas for further study.
Test-taking strategies and tips for maximizing performance on the final certification exam.
Discussion of exam format, content areas, and scoring criteria.
Final Q&A session to address any remaining questions or concerns before the exam.
Review of the PEACE framework and its application in diverse end-of-life scenarios.
